name: Polly Hill (horticulturist)
content:
Mary Louise Butcher "Polly" Hill (January 30, 1907 – April 25, 2007) was an American horticulturist best known for testing how well plants could survive in cold climates. She founded the Polly Hill Arboretum on Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts.
 Born in Ardmore, Pennsylvania, she graduated in 1928 from Vassar College. She went to Japan to teach English and learned about flower arrangement there.[citation needed] After returning to the United States, she studied botany and horticulture at the University of Maryland. She began her work in 1958 after inheriting what is now the arboretum from her parents.[citation needed]
 Hill died in Hockessin, Delaware at age 100.[1]
 
 This article about an American botanist is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.

For other people named Polly Hill, see Polly Hill (disambiguation).
This article relies largely or entirely on a single source. Relevant discussion may be found on the talk page. Please help improve this article by introducing citations to additional sources.Find sources: "Polly Hill" horticulturist – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR (July 2017)
Mary Louise Butcher "Polly" Hill (January 30, 1907 – April 25, 2007) was an American horticulturist best known for testing how well plants could survive in cold climates. She founded the Polly Hill Arboretum on Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts.
Born in Ardmore, Pennsylvania, she graduated in 1928 from Vassar College. She went to Japan to teach English and learned about flower arrangement there.[citation needed] After returning to the United States, she studied botany and horticulture at the University of Maryland. She began her work in 1958 after inheriting what is now the arboretum from her parents.[citation needed]

Death[edit]
Hill died in Hockessin, Delaware at age 100.[1]

References[edit]


^ Hevesi, Dennis (April 30, 2007). "Polly Hill Is Dead at 100; Tested Hardiness of Plants", New York Times; accessed July 22, 2017.
